response.answer_text: In hind sight it is easy to say the Vietnam War was a mistake. The way the war ended was not the outcome that those that escalated the fighting hoped for. The US had been doing a bunch of back peddling, starting with Kennedy. The bailing out of the Bay of Pigs was a big fiasco. This made Kennedy seem weak. Then the Soviets began building the Berlin Wall, and all JFK does is give his “I am a Berliner” speech. The Communists and military people in the US begin seeing Kennedy as weak. Kennedy finally stands up to the Communists during the Cuban Missile Crisis, but at the risk of nuclear war. Then JFK announces a troop reduction in Vietnam. Kennedy doesn’t understand military power, many Americans begin murmuring, remembering their glory days of WW2. With Kennedy’s assassination, LBJ goes back to the Democratic play book, and announces American boys shouldn’t have to go eight thousand miles away to fight a war that Asian boys should be fighting for themselves. Keep Americans out of the war till reelected is what Johnson really means. Johnson relies on Secretary of Defense McNamara’s judgment, which is the US is technically much more capable that the peasant rice growing soldiers of the communist. With a more savvy and better educated military, the US should make mince meat out of the communist opposition. That was McNamara’s reasoning, a super Brainiac that had all the answers. Home field advantage never entered into his reasoning. Johnson and Nixon preferred Carpet Bombing, 60,000 pounds at a time with B 52’s. General Westmoreland was convinced the war was almost over because the communist were slowing down on their offensives. The end is insight, the General proclaimed, not knowing the Communists were gearing up for the largest offensive of the war, called Tet. McNamara came to the conclusion that after another 100,000 Ameicans had been added to the war effort without any significant changes in the outcome, that the Vietnam couldn’t be won. That didn’t slow down the fighting. Now a way had to be figured out of how to get America out of the war. The Communists took a terrible beating with their Tet Offensive, the Viet Cong, the communist rebels in South Vietnam, had been greatly diminished as a fighting force. But the Communists were more than buoyed by the growing anti war movement in the US. Nixon had to call on the Silent Majority, as the war protesters were weakening the US peace position. Nixon secretly expanded the Vietnam War into Cambodia and Laos. Four days later when this was exposed, Ohio Guardsmen fired on Kent State college protesters, killing four. As if Nixon didn’t have enough problems with the war, Nixon got embroiled in the Watergate break in cover up, part of his own making. Nixon and Kissinger secretly worked out a peace deal, where US POW’s would be released, and South Vietnamese would now do their own fighting, while the North stayed up in North Vietnam. Little did Congress know that Nixon had secretly promised the North war reparations as part of the deal for the return of US POW’s. The North had sought a ransom price, based on JFK paying Castro for the release of the Bay of Pig prisoners. The North had released half the POW’s, including John McCain, to seal up the Peace Accords, with the second half to be released after the reparation payments. When Nixon resigned, Congress did not know of this secret payment arrangement, and refused North Vietnam’s request for reparations. These POW’s were abandoned, and movies like Rambo, and ones starring Chuck Norris showed fake rescued of abandoned POW’s. More POW’s were held in Cambodia and Laos, who also wanted payments that never came. The way the war ended showed the war should never have been fought. The way Communist Vietnam is today is not totally barbaric as prophesized in the early years of the US involvement. The end objective of the US scurrying out of Vietnam, definitely didn’t justify the cost of 58,000 dead Americans, and 400,000 injured. A war that doesn’t accomplish anything, shouldn’t be fought, and Vietnam was such a war.

War Is A Racket" THE VIETNAM WAR - THE COSTLIEST TO DATE It's been 40 years since the U.S. ended its involvement in the Vietnam War, and yet payments for the conflict are still rising. Now above $22 billion annually, Vietnam compensation costs are roughly twice the size of the FBI's annual budget. And while many disabled Vietnam vets have been compensated for post-traumatic stress disorder, hearing loss or general wounds, other ailments are positioning the war to have large costs even after veterans die. Based on an uncertain link to the defoliant Agent Orange that was used in Vietnam, federal officials approved diabetes a decade ago as an ailment that qualifies for cash compensation — and it is now the most compensated ailment for Vietnam vets. The VA also recently included heart disease among the Vietnam medical problems that qualify, and the agency is seeing thousands of new claims for that condition. THE PRESENT If history is any judge, the U.S. government will be paying for the Iraq and Afghanistan wars for the next century as service members and their families grapple with the sacrifices of combat. An Associated Press analysis of federal payment records found that the government is still making monthly payments to relatives of Civil War veterans — 148 years after the conflict ended. At the 10-year anniversary of the start of the Iraq War, more than $40 billion a year is going to compensate veterans and survivors from the Spanish-American War from 1898, World War I and II, the Korean War, the Vietnam War, the two Iraq campaigns and the Afghanistan conflict. And those costs are rising rapidly. U.S. Sen. Patty Murray said such expenses should remind the nation about war's long-lasting financial toll. "When we decide to go to war, we have to consciously be also thinking about the cost," said Murray, D-Wash., adding that her WWII veteran father's disability benefits helped feed their family.” With greater numbers of troops surviving combat injuries because of improvements in battlefield medicine and technology, the costs of disability payments are set to rise much higher. THE IRAQ WARS AND AFGHANISTAN So far, the wars in Iraq, Afghanistan and the first Persian Gulf conflict in the early 1990s are costing about $12 billion a year to compensate those who have left military service or family members of those who have died. Those post-service compensation costs have totaled more than $50 billion since 2003, not including expenses of medical care and other benefits provided to veterans, and are poised to grow for many years to come. The new veterans are filing for disabilities at historic rates, with about 45 percent of those from Iraq and Afghanistan seeking compensation for injuries. Many are seeking compensation for a variety of ailments at once. Experts see a variety of factors driving that surge, including a bad economy that's led more jobless veterans to seek the financial benefits they've earned, troops who survive wounds of war, and more awareness about head trauma and mental health.
